title: Will the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and/or the EU's European Medicines Agency (EMA) approve a COVID-19 vaccine from Chinese companies Sinovac or Sinopharm before 1 September 2021?
possible_answers: Yes, by both the FDA and the EMA
preds: Updating from 0/1/0/99 due to passage of time, and holidays in Europe.
Let's close this question.  Not enough time left.
Missed to update this. Always thought i had 100% down for No.
US lobbying will avoid any rapid advances in approval, and neither US nor EU tend to get much of anything done in August.
NOpe, EU on holiday and most susceptible; US also on holiday and antagonistic
EMA doesn’t have a meeting scheduled in this timeframe, and August is a dead season for policymaking in the EU.
Updating from 0/3/0/97 due to passage of time.

There seem to be real issues with the Chinese vaccines (https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/covid-vaccines-delta-china-asia/2021/08/10/24d0df60-f664-11eb-a636-18cac59a98dc_story.html). Time passes, August is a month when even European organizations have many of their staff in summer vacation - I am moving "No" to 100%.

This [1] could be a motivation for EMA, to bring the EU policies more in line with each other. 
Sinovac is the second most common vaccine globally (https://www.biospace.com/article/-acceptance-of-sinovac-s-covid-19-vaccine-grows-across-the-globe-despite-hurdles-and-disparate-efficacy-data/).  On the other hand, rolling review continues for CureVac, Novavax, Sinovac, Sputnik V, and now also Sanofi-GSK (https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/7/20/eu-begins-real-time-review-of-sanofi-gsk-covid-19-vaccine), and the time is running out on this question.  [1] https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/travel-only-6-eu-schengen-countries-recognise-chinas-sinovac-vaccine-as-valid-proof-of-immunity/ "According to a new tool developed by VisaGuide.World, which enables travellers to check the validity of their vaccine when travelling abroad, the following EU/Schengen Area countries accept Sinovac as valid proof of immunity:
Austria
Finland
Greece
Iceland
Netherlands
Spain
Switzerland"

Updating from 0/5/0/95 due to passage of time. Novavax, Curevac, and Sputnik all still unapproved in spite of 5-6 months in rolling review. Sinovac entered rolling review ~3 months ago. Last week EMA also started rolling review of the Sanofi vaccine, not sure what that means for this question.
FWIW, more questionable results for a Chinese vaccine: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-23/study-chinese-covid-shot-may-offer-elderly-poor-protection
At this point, I don't see a motivation.
The 4% is for the unbinding medical opinion about effeciency of Chinease vaccines agains Delta, but Usa will not accept by any way to use& like wise China if condition is reversed.

Questions as to whether Chinese vaccines are comparatively effective against the Delta variant of COVID: https://www.reuters.com/world/china/are-chinese-covid-19-shots-effective-against-delta-variant-2021-06-29/
Until we know the source of COVID, neither the FDA or EMA is going to approve anything produced in China.

Updating from 0/7/1/92 due to passage of time. EMA started rolling review for Sinovac on 4 May 2021 [1]. Novavax, Curevac, and Sputnik are already in rolling review, having started on 3 Feb, 12 Feb, and 4 Mar respectively. Sputnik is probably delayed now due to data issues [2], which on the one hand is bad for Sinovac as a "base rate", but is good in the sense that it probably frees up manpower to work on Sinovac. Still, Novavax and Curevac are ~3 months ahead of Sinovac and still no approval; and we are ~2 months from the deadline. Thanks @timothy_chan for the pointers, you can see his original post here [3]. [1] https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/news/ema-starts-rolling-review-covid-19-vaccine-vero-cell-inactivated
[2] https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/16/eu-delays-russias-sputnik-v-covid-vaccine-approval-reuters-a74233
[3] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1281693
I'm curious what the coronavirus challenge leaderboard members are thinking.

There may be pressure to recognize the Chinese vaccines from member states with ties to Africa: https://news.abs-cbn.com/overseas/06/19/21/chinese-jab-a-hurdle-for-some-african-visitors-to-eu But EMA head insists on retaining the agency’s independence: https://www.ft.com/content/b79b24fb-90bb-4720-98f2-d72fe21d342b
In the same article, more results on AZ are expected in September.  Sputnik approval is delayed—whatever that means for the Chinese vaccines. https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/16/eu-delays-russias-sputnik-v-covid-vaccine-approval-reuters-a74233
More reported issues with Sinovac's effectiveness: https://www.forbes.com/sites/roberthart/2021/06/17/chinas-sinovac-vaccine-under-scrutiny-as-covid-soars-in-highly-vaccinated-countries/
Will Greece’s decision affect the EMA? https://www.ekathimerini.com/news/1162769/greece-to-accept-all-jabs-for-entry-into-the-country/

U.S. plans to donate 500M Pfizer doses 'to the world. Also: Another country (Mongolia) is seeing rising infections after Sinopharm was widely administered. (https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/09/world/mongolia-covid-sinopharm-vaccine.html)
US releasing AZ, J&J, Pfzier and Mod. why would CN vaccine be approved.
Excellent work by @timothy_chan. I'd guess approval is fairly likely but much less likely within the the timeframe of the question.

Copying @timothy_chan forecast below for reference, but updating conclusions down for geopolitics and for concerns about the vaccine safety and efficacy: ==================================================================
Sinovac rolling review began on 04/05/2021 (DD/MM/YY) https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/news/ema-starts-rolling-review-covid-19-vaccine-vero-cell-inactivated
21 days since 
119 days between start of rolling review and forecast question closing date. Base rate for approval 
Vaccines approved by EMA 
Janssen 
https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/news/ema-starts-rolling-review-janssens-covid-19-vaccine-ad26cov2s (01/12/2020) 
https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/news/ema-recommends-covid-19-vaccine-janssen-authorisation-eu (11/03/2021) 
100 days between start of rolling review and approval AstraZeneca 
https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/news/ema-starts-first-rolling-review-covid-19-vaccine-eu (01/10/2020) 
https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/news/ema-recommends-covid-19-vaccine-astrazeneca-authorisation-eu (29/01/2021) 
120 days between start of rolling review and approval BioNTech/Pfizer 
https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/news/ema-starts-second-rolling-review-covid-19-vaccine (06/10/2020) 
https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/news/ema-recommends-first-covid-19-vaccine-authorisation-eu (21/12/2020) 
76 days between start of rolling review and approval Moderna 
https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/news/ema-starts-rolling-review-mrna-covid-19-vaccine-moderna-biotech-spain-sl (16/11/2020) 
https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/news/ema-recommends-covid-19-vaccine-moderna-authorisation-eu (06/01/2021) 
51 days between start of rolling review and approval 86.75 days average 
Although the early approvals might have been sped up because of the urgency. **110 days average for the two vaccines approved later.** Vaccines under rolling review (other than Sinovac) 
https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/documents/presentation/presentation-update-approved-candidate-covid-19-vaccines-eu-mcavaleri-ema_en.pdf Sputnik V (Start of rolling review: 04/03/2021) 
82 days since CureVac (Start of rolling review: 12/02/2021) 
**102 days since** Novavax (Start of rolling review: 03/02/2021) 
**111 days since** Might be worth keeping track of the other vaccines under rolling review. From the above, it looks like ~110 days might be a suitable estimate for a lower bound for approval of the Sinovac vaccine. Taking into account the question closing date, this leaves about 9 days extra for approval. Not sure about how much geopolitics will play a role in approval. Let's say if it is approved, it delays it by at least a few days, so fewer days left for approval in expectation

Two COVID vaccines from Sinopharm are over 70% effective against symptomatic cases, per a recent study: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-sinopharm-vaccines/sinopharms-two-covid-19-shots-effective-study-says-idUSKCN2D80CT Also (per comments below): The EMA has reportedly initiated a "rolling review" of Sinovac's Vero Cell vaccine: https://www.europeanpharmaceuticalreview.com/news/153681/ema-begins-rolling-reviews-for-a-covid-19-therapeutic-and-a-vaccine/

EMA is requesting more data from Janssen (J&J) for its vaccine that is already in use under EUA.
Further reports on contaminated AstraZeneca vaccine charges found at the University of Ulm (Germany) cannot be explained completely by the manufacturer which refers to highest standards in production processes, however, the additional proteins found in the vaccine may relate to the production process.
It raises some concerns about production process standards in Chinese manufacturing, and safety concerns will be doubled up. EMA will demand more info and data on both Sinovac and Sinopharm vaccines, even though the latter one is reportedly in the approval process already. Because trustworthiness is key to vaccination campaigns and reaching herd immunization, EMA has no room for failure, and will have zero tolerance for unclear dataand will not compromise.
One or both of the Chinese vaccines may ultimately be authorized, but likely not before 01 September 2021.

Anything involving diplomacy with China in the short term is a non-starter, until the situation with the origin of COVID-19 is resolved or the Wuhan laboratory is cleared as the source.

WHO EUA is significant: https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20210507-who-approves-a-covid-19-vaccine-from-china-s-sinopharm-for-emergency-use
EU starts considering its EUA: https://fortune.com/2021/05/04/coronavac-sinovac-covid-vaccine-eu-ema-rolling-review/ This is contingent, however, on availability of data. 
"Other vaccines in the EMA's pipeline include Russia's Sputnik V, Germany's CureVac, and the U.S.'s Novavax. The agency has already green-lit the BioNTech/Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines."
Also: "A specific timeframe for the review is not provided, but the EMA said the process should "take less time than normal." https://www.globaltimes.cn/page/202105/1222712.shtml
Upping the probability now that the process has started.

Huge waves in the Maldives and the Seychelles, which have very high levels of vaccination, and in both cases about half are with Sinopharm (other half is Astrazeneca/Covishield). Edit: 22/05/2021
Also I have questions about efficacy of Sinovac with respect to the P1 variant, looking at Uruguay and Chile.

Sinopharm's effectiveness is being called into question after a "surge" of cases in the Seychelles involving already-vaccinated individuals: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/12/business/economy/covid-seychelles-sinopharm.html
They are trying hard to create a better media enviroment to promote the new vaccine, but it is going to be really hard to get US or EU approvals.

Not sure what to make of the EMA's rolling review of the vaccine. Apparently WHO approved the vaccine which makes it seem like it has a good chance of being approved in Europe. I'm tempted to put more weight on the yes only by EMA bucket due to that, I guess I'm not sure why it would be rejected by Europe at this point, I would think if Europe had no intention of approving it it wouldn't start the rolling review process at all and the fact that WHO approved it seems to be a sign that the EMA will probably approve it. I guess the other big factor is time, I'm not sure what other data the EMA would need before they would consider the rolling review completed.

Think I got this one wrong. Recent scares combined with relatively abundant existing supplies particularly in the us make it seem unlikely other vaccines will be approved quickly and without long study
Adjusting for WHO approval of Sinopharm vaccine ('emergency use') plus current EMA review of it. https://fortune.com/2021/05/04/coronavac-sinovac-covid-vaccine-eu-ema-rolling-review/

WHO just granted Chinese Sinopharm vaccine, thereby increasing the odds that EMA would also follow suit. Uncertainty remains regarding timing and the effectiveness of each vaccine in question.
https://www.chicagotribune.com/coronavirus/vaccine/ct-who-china-sinopharm-vaccine-20210507-ca77z2fiz5fm3ivxvrzulwtozi-story.html

I'm almost split because there are reports that there are adverse side effects, yet a lot of the EMA criteria are met, yet timing might be a tight fit, yet these vaccines are much easier to transport and give to nations lagging behind. Furthermore, other countries have approved the Chinese vaccine(s) so there is evidence that authorities are liking what they're seeing. I also think it's pushing it that of multiple vaccines under review this week, only one or none get approved. I also don't see evidence that countries are rescinding or pausing their approvals because of an unexpected effect from these vaccines. I also read an article that says it is expected to be faster than normal. I have read from other forecasters that normal seems to be 3 or 4 months. There are 4 months left to question closing date. Subconsciously, if EMA says it will take a shorter time than average and end up disapproving both vaccines, what kind of message does that send out? That EMA already made up their mind and so will hastily deem China's hard work not enough?

EMA has started a rolling review on a Sinovac vaccine. But September is not far off and it sounds like they may not have enough data to support an approval yet. https://fortune.com/2021/05/04/coronavac-sinovac-covid-vaccine-eu-ema-rolling-review/
40 % might be too high for "Yes, EMA only", although review started.

https://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/eu-regulators-start-review-chinas-sinovac-vaccine-77480581 Don't know how long it would take. Other vaccines are enlisted since February (https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/human-regulatory/overview/public-health-threats/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/treatments-vaccines/vaccines-covid-19/covid-19-vaccines-under-evaluation#covid-19-vaccines-under-rolling-review-section)

European Parliament excluded Sinopharm from the “vaccine passport” (so far). 
https://hungarytoday.hu/vaccine-passport-hungary-immunity-certificate-eu-vaccines-european-parliament-vaccines-hungary-travel/

No reason for an FDA approval. EMA slightly more likely but the sanctions row isn’t helping. Sputnik V was a little ahead in the process of EMA review and may get an approval next month. 
https://www.google.ca/amp/s/www.euronews.com/amp/2021/04/22/covid-19-germany-to-buy-30-million-doses-of-russia-s-sputnik-v-vaccine-pending-regulator-a
Vaccines will remain N. American or European for said populations
The U.S. will not need an inactivated virus form of the vaccine.
Rejigging based on some of the links provided suggesting the Chinese government admits the vaccines are not very effective.
Both the FDA and the EMA will approve it based on the studies made in chile.
Strange horse trading approach of Chinese firms and government with regards to effectiveness data, a behavior that will not raise anything except eyebrows at EMA or FDA.
Update based on this blog entry https://blogs.sciencemag.org/pipeline/archives/2021/04/12/vaccine-efficacy-questions

https://apnews.com/article/beijing-immunizations-chengdu-coronavirus-pandemic-china-675bcb6b5710c7329823148ffbff6ef9?utm_source=morning_brew News that Chinese vaccines may not be as effective causes me to adjust my already low estimate down even further. I just don't see Sinovac of Sinopharm applying for approval until they are likely to get it, and confusion about efficacy results makes that less likely.
Updating from 0/9/1/90 [1] due to passage of time. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1248804

PRC authorities have announced that these vaccines are not as effective as they had hoped, so they're looking at some options.  This pretty much zeroes out this Q, in case either of the US or the EU was feeling tempted.
On recent news of ineffectiveness of Chinese vaccines.
Geopolitics moving Europe away from China influence
It looks like there is no progress on getting the Chinese vaccines approved by the US and EU. If anything it will be Russian Sputnik V that will get approved by the EMA.
I previously predicted a higher probability of EMA approval, but it appears that the vaccination drive in europe is ramping up, reducing pressure on the EU to seek alternative vaccine sources.

If either EMA or FDA approved, the other would likely do the same. But there are enough vaccines approved and enough on the pipeline that would be willing to undergo the FDA or EMA scrutiny. Chinese companies seem to be delaying the decision and they are not showing much transparency on the process and results. I would reconsider, if a Chinese vaccine would apply for a BLA/MAA or they were more transparent.

EU vaccine passport unlikely to include vaccines unapproved by the EMA. So this puts pressure, from inside and outside of the EU, for the approval process for these vaccines to begin. So for now I increase EMA by 4 percentage points.
Given the slow rate of vaccine approval in Europe, it might happen. From the US side I don't see it.

I see an outside chance of the EMA approving a vaccine due to being pushed to by widespread use by member states, and a sluggish vaccination campaign. I see a smaller but non-zero chance of the FDA approving a vaccine if EMA and other bodies in Australia, NZ, and Singapore approve a vaccine, and the drug-maker submits it for approval to the FDA, but I think it is extremely unlikely to happen before 1st Sept.

It seems very unlikely that both the FDA and EMA will approve a Chinese vaccine. The tensions between the US and China are too high and the EU just pulled (with very little evidence) the AstraZeneca vaccine. They seem to be much more hesitant. That said, the EU's anemic response to vaccinations so far may force them into a dire position. Even though, it will be tough, so the good money should be on the fact that neither block approves a Chinese vaccine.
inertia has developed in EU on vaccine approvals. Will pay the price with lockdowns and swing roll out of vaccinations

No big pressure as there are so many companies offering vaccines.
September will be no more need for big quantities.
EU must approve if applied correctly, US will protect own market.

Updating from 0/13/1/86 due to passage of time and additional considerations for Europe. FDA will never approve these, they have barely approved the 3 American/European ones we have. Who knows when they will even approve Novavax and AstraZeneca. As for Europe, it seems that countries can authorize vaccines inside their own borders, so the incentive/push to get EMA approval is correspondingly weaker. Czech Republic is using Sputnik right now, Hungary is using Sinopharm, why would they care what EMA says? (Of course Czech and Hungarian DOCTORS are against this, at least the ones in high positions. The medical communities of the whole western world have massively failed the test of this pandemic.) Also it lets EMA members ask, "why don't you just approve this in your country if you want it so bad?" The deadline of this question is 1 Sep 2021, but I think by June-July the pandemic will be all but gone. Not just because vaccination of at least the rich countries will be far along, but also the advent of summer will naturally bring cases way down. So there will be little urgency to bring in more vaccines.
Giving a little more points to a possible EMA approval due to Hungary's own approval and distribution of Sinopharm vaccine. Hungary is part of the EU.

I was optimistic seeing one of these on the EMA site a few months ago, but both companies seem to have significantly lower efficacy rates than other candidates. Maybe if the companies tweak their vaccines could the chances of approval increase???
No incentive to push thru by Chinese firms or USA /EU to accelerate the process, as far as national firm provides vaccines in each territories.
Adjusting a little bit for some new kind of vaccine approval, i.e. not the current Chinese vaccines.

So far there is not much talk in the press that this is an option for the EMA or the FDA.
Biden appears to have commitments from Moderna and Pfizer for enough for the summer and if J&J is approved the US should not need other suppliers except perhaps Novavax which the US heavily supported.
More choices and more suppliers make for more jabs.

It seems that because Europe has fallen behind in the vaccinations procurement, it might authorize the Chinese vaccines. So there is a need but not clear if these vaccines can pass the European rules to be approved.

FWIW, Russia reportedly "..expect(s) E.U. clearance by March.." for its 'Sputnik V' vaccine.     Also reportedly: "The European Medicines Agency said it is providing scientific advice for applications by Sputnik V and one of the Chinese vaccines, Sinovac, though neither has yet submitted a request for E.U. approval." Source: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/europe-vaccines-russia-china-germany-serbia/2021/02/04/cd1f674c-655d-11eb-bab8-707f8769d785_story.html

The EU/EMA may be under increasing pressure to procure additional vaccines. Hungary has (separately) approved the Sinopharm vaccine and reportedly has signed a deal to order some. (https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-europe-tripped-in-covid-19-vaccine-race-11612293218, https://apnews.com/article/europe-coronavirus-pandemic-china-coronavirus-vaccine-hungary-a598b6170a1ca9eb120ac4b87e73636c)

Need to dig into this more, but updating on suggestions in the comments that EU might be pressured by member countries to approve. This aligns with my perception that the EU is going to be tight on vaccines for quite a while since it seems that their vaccine agreements came later than the US agreements, so US gets priority from the big vaccine manufacturers at the moment. Going up 10 on EMA alone and down 10 on no.
Europe will most likely be more pre-disposed to approve a Chinese vaccine and the US is unlikely to do it on teh national security grounds.
@TheLopen and @Econja2018 shared articles that indicate shift toward yes for Europe.

Updated forecast weighting the likelihood differently.  Less likely EMA will approve Chinese vaccine due to China's development not consulting EMA:https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-europe-vaccines/russia-and-china-have-not-sought-emas-authorisation-for-vaccines-idUSKBN28J0YC

There are reports of counterfeit vaccines made and sold in China, so the Chinese mafia/organized crime apparently has discovered a new field of business.
That will make it harder to convince regulators outside of China of the safety of the process.

https://www.dw.com/en/coronavirus-germany-open-to-chinese-and-russian-vaccines-amid-delays/a-56396510
-Germany's Federal Health Minister Jens Spahn has hinted that coronavirus vaccines from China and Russia could be used in Europe to overcome the current deficit of doses.
-"Regardless of the country in which a vaccine is manufactured, if they are safe and effective, they can help cope with the pandemic," Spahn told the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung newspaper on Sunday, adding that they must be approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA). Combined with the sputtering supply in the EU, looks like a tick toward being possible
With vaccines being harder to produce at the moment, there is a chance that the EMA will and I believe the FDA may then follow suit.
Going up on no based on low effectiveness of one vaccine and following the crowd a bit.

https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/27/world/europe/eu-uk-covid-vaccine.html
Production delays in Europe and competition over vaccines between the EU and UK may lead the EU to be more willing to accept a Chinese vaccine
Probably never. If yes, then much later, maybe in 2-3 years from 2022.

No evidence of ongoing evaluation despite the high incidence of the epidemic.
And the other forecasters are increasingly converging towards a lack of approval.

https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/25/business/china-covid-19-vaccine-backlash.html
-Slight uptick for no due to continuing concerns about the lack of data
- Additionally, the article states sinopharm and sinovac will be able to produce 1 billion doses each per year. With so much commitment to supplying developing countries as well as its own people, the possibility of pushing for western approval decreases

Revising my forecast to take account of increasing public recognition of China's clumsy vaccine diplomacy, the lack of effectiveness of their shots, and the PRC Foreign Ministry's ham-handed attempts to undermine confidence in U.S. and European vaccines.[1]  Stories like those in the New York Times will have a powerful effect in Washington and EU capitals and substantially decrease the likelihood of regulators having a sense of urgency to approve Chinese vaccines. [1]  https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/25/business/china-covid-19-vaccine-backlash.html
Neither institution will devote the resources to evaluating a Chinese vaccine.

Strong, very strong supranationalist  (27 European countries) reaction. Not a single mention about Chinese vaccines, all delegates are looking toward Pfizer vaccine.  2021-01-19
"In a The debate also touched upon other issues, such as the need for comparable national data and mutual recognition of vaccinations, the need to avoid delays and increase the speed of vaccination, as well as the unconstructive nature of blaming the EU or the pharmaceutical industry for any failures."
Press service European Parlement https://www.europarl.europa.eu/plenary/en/vod.html?mode=chapter&vodLanguage=EN&vodId=bd100444-e90a-86a9-86ab-0f69189e39de&date=20210119#
Adjusting for the negative news on performance of the vaccine

I am concerned about Sinova and Sinopharm not releasing their data or trying to publish results. Sinovac has 50.3% efficacy in Brazil, which is borderline. I am highly in agreement with the crowd forecast of 90% no. I am also concerned about the lack of transparency with Sinopharm. I think the Chinese government will go ahead with the vaccines and the companies won't feel the need to release the data, partly due to lower efficacy or substandard protocol, and there will be large enough market in China.

Scaling back on the news of only 51% effectiveness. Nevertheless I think there is a non-trivial chance for approval due to the lack of availability of the higher-performance vaccines. But this data makes it much less likely for Sinovac/Sinopharm/the CCP to decide it's worth spending the effort with these two regulatory agencies, rather than investing that effort into other countries.

Bahrain also approved the Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine, saying adults could register online to receive the jab for free.
And Singapore said it had signed advance purchase agreements with vaccine makers including Sinovac, Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech.Sinovac is also known to have secured other deals with Turkey, Brazil and Chile.

Largely no. These companies are no doubt aware of the saturation of the western markets and have been since the beginning of the pandemic. Their trials and most of their pre-orders have come from developing countries in Asia, Africa, and South America. These markets will not have access to nearly as many of the early western vaccines. This opportunity for these Chinese companies to make money and for the expansion of Chinese soft power will keep their efforts focused on the developing world.

I think most here are missing one point in how approval works. At least in Europe (but I think FDA is the same) you need to provide better results, either effectiveness or less side effects (or some combination thereof), than the current state of care. This is after you have proven safety (phase I & II trials). The reason why the few new vaccines pass stage three is that showing statistically better results is hard for things where effective vaccines already exist or, if non exists yet, there are very few cases and therefore the statistical significance is not reached in a reasonable amount of time (making it more likely to be a financial loss). 
For Covid on these two reasons are non-issues. At least for the first couple of vaccines. I'm not sure how this translates to later applications though and I don't think it is a relevant contribution to the resolution of this question. I think here it is a combination of 
a) does China consider a diplomatic victory more important than immunising their own population?
b) does the production capacity suffice to make a) irrelevant b/c they can just supply everyone?
c) does China think their data would stand up to EMA/FDA scrutiny? I think we can answer a) relatively safely with yes as evidenced by supplications to Indonesia, Turkey and Brazil. Some of that may be due to their own lack of pandemic activity and therefore limited efficacy testability at home, but I do not believe that they didn't also get some kind of concession politically. About b) I'm very unsure, I do not think it is too relevant though as China seems to have the spread "under control" by just locking up a few million at a time (it's a sledgehammer but it seems to work). So I do think it essentially comes down to c) and I have no idea there. I do think the window of opportunity is closing though and there are other countries (e.g. Afrika) where China can extract more political concessions with more ... mendable ... public health systems.
Quality assurance and safety inspections likely to be an issue, plus general public would be very reluctant to receive a Chinese vaccine.

Few elements to this. First are these vaccines going to be safe and effective by “Western” standards. Second will the Chinese companies want to put it forward for EU/US approval. Third will the EU/US want to approve it. On the first point, I have mainly used the data under clinical trials here. https://www.goodrx.com/blog/coronavirus-covid-19-vaccine-availability-live-updates/
This suggests for a vaccine at the start of clinical trials there is about a 5% chance of getting through and for a vaccine in stage 3 at 20 - 30%. So for at least one of two that would be more like 10% and 36 - 51% if they are “independent”. These vaccines are all in phase 3 trials somewhere from the news reports. It also seems that so far covid vaccines have done better on phase 3 approvals than the 30% would suggest. It also seems these trials are generally going well, despite one or two incidents (which other vaccines also had). On the flip side these are generally tests in jurisdictions that sound more lax and disinformation from a Chinese company would not be unheard of. In addition, I understand these are vaccines of the same “type” so may be the results are correlated and these are traditional so the fact that so far covid vaccines have done well may not be relevant. All in, particularly the fact that they might not be “independent” I am going for 30% at this point for this “limb”. I think the Chinese will want EU and/or FDA approval if they can get it. They will want to roll out globally and this will be a stamp of approval as well as a diplomatic victory. They probably would not want to be refused, but that is to an extent filtered out by step 1 above (albeit maybe if it is “close” they will be cautious). Hard to put a number on this but I am thinking high - 80% for now. Cannot seem to find much on the two companies intentions which would help. Step 3 - it does not look like they stop approving vaccines because they have one, even where the new one is less effective on some measures. People have also stated (from memory) that we will want several vaccines. Let’s call this 85% for now. Might be higher for EU than US, especially given that China and EU seem to have better relations. First two stages gets you to 24% third stage gets you to 20%. But of smoothing gets you the distributions above.

Just a first level approximation.   If the administration weren’t changing in January, I would have this question at zero for US approval (More of a negative number, Trump would rather poke his eye out with a pencil than allow China to profit off of the virus).  The inherent distrust that has been created this year would color the acceptance by the US on both motives and reliability.  Any distrust of vaccines would be multiplied by a factor of 100 if the vaccine came from within the country where it is perceived to have originated.  This would tend to limit application to the FDA by Chinese firms for two reasons: 1) They do not have a current contract with the US government to purchase the drug, and they are the only ones currently buying. There is no reason to apply without a guarantee of profit.  2) There is a huge non US Market where China could use providing the vaccine as both a source of profit and good will to consolidate its power and prestige. They do not need the hassle of applying in the US.  As far as the EU, after reading through the source materials, I do not see the same antagonism towards China that would make such an approval an issue.  I can see them applying to the EU.  So my estimate is not based upon whether the vaccine works or could be approved if they applied, it is based on whether China would even apply. 5% is probably too high, but I am hedging my bets on this one.

BASE RATES
It seems the US has never approved a Chinese vaccine, for any disease [1,2]. So, 1% for FDA. I wasn't able to find such clear information about the EU, but my prior is that it's similar, and the EU-China trade breakdown shows "medicaments" as very very small fraction of EU imports from China [3]. So 20% for EMA (from "epistemic" uncertainty more than factual uncertainty). Btw, how did I manage the miracle of googling "chinese vaccine" and getting something besides covid19 results? I just set the time range of the search to end on Dec 2019. INSIDE VIEW
Base rates might be overridden if China was the only game in town. But, there are already ~5 companies with a very big chance of having vaccines approved by March 2021, and another ~5 by September. So I don't see how the Chinese ones would become a priority. EMA hasn't even gotten around to approving Pfizer or Moderna, so they seem even slower than FDA, at least on this, but not by much. One crucial thing that might bring the EMA odds way down is if any decision had to be unanimous by all member states (as so many EU decisions have to be). I would have given EMA 1% odds at best in that case. But they don't have to be unanimous; a majority suffices [4, p.6]. Finally, due to geopolitics, I don't see a way for FDA to approve but not EMA. I feel like FDA would only approve in some very dire scenario that would likely be worldwide (say, several of the now-promising vaccines turn out not to work). So I'll put the FDA 1% in the "both" bucket. [1] https://vaxopedia.org/2017/11/12/vaccines-are-made-in-china/
